articles.headline: As Syrian Rebels Advance, Iran Grows Nervous and Neighbors Close Their Borders
articles.snippet: The rebels’ gains prompted Lebanon and Jordan to close border crossings and Iran to begin withdrawing personnel from Syria.
articles.abstract: The rebels’ gains prompted Lebanon and Jordan to close border crossings and Iran to begin withdrawing personnel from Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: The collection of rebel groups fighting to depose President Bashar al-Assad of Syria pushed further south on Friday toward a major city en route to the capital, as the government’s chief patron, Iran, moved to evacuate military commanders and other personnel from the country.
articles.byline: By Raja Abdulrahim, Farnaz Fassihi and Thomas Fuller

articles.headline: A Second Trump Term Is Set to Scramble Trade Alliances
articles.snippet: Europe’s new pact with South America, its largest deal to date, could be a sign of how countries will diversify trade relationships as Donald Trump threatens tariffs.
articles.abstract: Europe’s new pact with South America, its largest deal to date, could be a sign of how countries will diversify trade relationships as Donald Trump threatens tariffs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even before stepping back into the Oval Office, President-elect Donald J. Trump is prompting governments across the globe to rethink their trading relationships as they prepare for a four-year period in which business with the United States could become much more volatile.

articles.headline: The Silicon Valley Billionaires Steering Trump’s Transition
articles.snippet: The involvement of wealthy investors has made this presidential transition one of the most potentially conflict-ridden in modern history.
articles.abstract: The involvement of wealthy investors has made this presidential transition one of the most potentially conflict-ridden in modern history.
articles.lead_paragraph: The week after the November election, President-elect Donald J. Trump gathered his top advisers in the tearoom at his Florida resort, Mar-a-Lago, to plan the transition to his second-term government.
articles.byline: By Theodore Schleifer, Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan

articles.headline: What if Charity Shouldn’t Be Optimized?
articles.snippet: The recent trend in philanthropy has been to look for the most bang for your buck. Maybe you don’t have to.
articles.abstract: The recent trend in philanthropy has been to look for the most bang for your buck. Maybe you don’t have to.
articles.lead_paragraph: Equipped with tools to measure our calories, steps, working hours, wasted hours, water intake and sleep cycles, we have now been exhorted to measure our charitable impact, too. Books, podcasts, TikToks and digital guides implore us to donate our money cautiously, rationally, to the charities that promise to make a dollar go the furthest it can. Holiday season giving can start to feel a little like sports betting: It doesn’t matter if you’re loyal to a scrappy local team — the data can tell you exactly where your money should go.

articles.headline: Mortgage Regulators Are Shrugging Off Climate Risk. It Could Cost Taxpayers Billions.
articles.snippet: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, which backstop most U.S. mortgages, know floods and fires are a growing problem. But little action has been taken.
articles.abstract: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, which backstop most U.S. mortgages, know floods and fires are a growing problem. But little action has been taken.
articles.lead_paragraph: As sea levels rise and natural disasters become more intense, homes in low-lying coastal areas or tinder-dry mountains are starting to lose value.

articles.headline: Syria’s Government Battles Multiple Rebel Uprisings
articles.snippet: The longtime Syrian dictator Bashar al-Assad is facing threats from rebellions on numerous fronts as his key ally, Iran, is paring back support.
articles.abstract: The longtime Syrian dictator Bashar al-Assad is facing threats from rebellions on numerous fronts as his key ally, Iran, is paring back support.

articles.headline: South Korea’s Leader Survives Impeachment Vote After His Power Grab
articles.snippet: The country was thrown into deeper uncertainty after the governing party changed its stance and refused to oust him. Protesters vowed to keep the pressure on.
articles.abstract: The country was thrown into deeper uncertainty after the governing party changed its stance and refused to oust him. Protesters vowed to keep the pressure on.
articles.lead_paragraph: South Korean lawmakers’ attempt to impeach President Yoon Suk Yeol ended in failure on Saturday night, prolonging the political upheaval and uncertainty that has roiled the country since his short-lived imposition of martial law this week.

articles.headline: Want a Job in the Trump Administration? Be Prepared for the Loyalty Test.
articles.snippet: Applicants for government posts, including inside the Pentagon and the intelligence agencies, say they have been asked about their thoughts on Jan. 6 and who they believe won the 2020 election.
articles.abstract: Applicants for government posts, including inside the Pentagon and the intelligence agencies, say they have been asked about their thoughts on Jan. 6 and who they believe won the 2020 election.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the Trump transition offices in West Palm Beach, Fla., prospective occupants of high posts inside the Pentagon and the intelligence agencies typically run through a gamut of three to four interviews, conducted in recent weeks by a mix of Silicon Valley investors and innovators and a team of the MAGA faithful.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Syrians Mourn All They Have Lost, Even as They Celebrate
articles.snippet: Thoughts of loved ones dead or missing complicate joyous relief at the prospect of Bashar al-Assad’s losing power.
articles.abstract: Thoughts of loved ones dead or missing complicate joyous relief at the prospect of Bashar al-Assad’s losing power.
articles.lead_paragraph: For nearly all the years that the al-Assad family ruled Syria, silence reigned.  No one spoke freely, fearful of who might hear. Everyone knew the consequences of dissent: disappearance into government prisons, from which few ever returned.
articles.byline: By Vivian Yee, Raja Abdulrahim and Muhammad Haj Kadour

articles.headline: Top-Gun Navy Pilots Fly at the Extremes. Their Brains May Suffer.
articles.snippet: A confidential Navy program is studying whether intense fighter jet operations can cause devastating brain injuries in flight crews.
articles.abstract: A confidential Navy program is studying whether intense fighter jet operations can cause devastating brain injuries in flight crews.
articles.lead_paragraph: To produce the best of the best, the Navy’s elite TOPGUN flying school puts fighter pilots through a crucible of intense, aerial dogfighting maneuvers under crushing G forces. But behind the high-speed Hollywood heroics that the school is famous for, the Navy has grown concerned that the extreme flying may also be producing something else: brain injuries.

articles.headline: Apple Sued for Failing to Curtail Child Sexual Abuse Material on iCloud
articles.snippet: Victims of abuse are seeking more than $1.2 billion in damages, arguing that the company abandoned a 2021 system it developed to find abusive material.
articles.abstract: Victims of abuse are seeking more than $1.2 billion in damages, arguing that the company abandoned a 2021 system it developed to find abusive material.
articles.lead_paragraph: The abuse began when she was still an infant. A relative molested her, took photographs and swapped the images with others online. He allowed another man to spend time with her, multiplying the abuse.

articles.headline: Bogged Down in Ukraine, Russia Pays a Price in Syria
articles.snippet: With the fall of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, Vladimir V. Putin has suffered one of the biggest geopolitical setbacks of his quarter-century in power.
articles.abstract: With the fall of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, Vladimir V. Putin has suffered one of the biggest geopolitical setbacks of his quarter-century in power.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lines of Russian troops in desert khaki greeted President Vladimir V. Putin in Syria in 2017. Declaring that Moscow had accomplished its mission in Syria’s civil war, Mr. Putin pledged that Russia was there to stay.

articles.headline: The Campaign by Syrian Rebels to Topple Assad Was Swift
articles.snippet: President Bashar al-Assad had kept opposition forces at bay for a decade with help from Russia and Iran. But rebels struck at a moment of weakness for those countries.
articles.abstract: President Bashar al-Assad had kept opposition forces at bay for a decade with help from Russia and Iran. But rebels struck at a moment of weakness for those countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: The government of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, which had kept rebel forces at bay for more than a decade with Iranian and Russian military support, collapsed with astonishing speed on Sunday morning after an advance by opposition forces on the capital, Damascus.

articles.headline: India’s Luxury Property Market Is a Boon to Trump’s Business
articles.snippet: The Trump Organization finds a warm welcome in India, where status-hungry home buyers clamor for a famous American brand.
articles.abstract: The Trump Organization finds a warm welcome in India, where status-hungry home buyers clamor for a famous American brand.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump started his first campaign for the presidency, two Trump-branded buildings were going up in India, one in the financial capital of Mumbai and the other nearby in Pune. Before he won in 2016, the Trump Organization expanded its business in India, signing deals in two more big cities.
articles.byline: By Alex Travelli and Suhasini Raj

articles.headline: Ukraine Asks if Telegram, Its Favorite App, Is a Sleeper Agent
articles.snippet: The messaging app’s popularity has soared during the war with Russia, leading Ukrainian officials to increasingly weigh Telegram’s upsides against its security risks.
articles.abstract: The messaging app’s popularity has soared during the war with Russia, leading Ukrainian officials to increasingly weigh Telegram’s upsides against its security risks.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the nearly three years since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, the messaging app Telegram has been a lifeline for millions of Ukrainians. It provides information about coming attacks and helps communities organize food, medical aid and other support.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur and Adam Satariano

articles.headline: Desperate Haitians Who Fled to the Dominican Republic Are Being Sent Back in Cages
articles.snippet: Relations between the neighboring countries on the island of Hispaniola have long been frosty. They are now complicated by up to 10,000 deportations a week.
articles.abstract: Relations between the neighboring countries on the island of Hispaniola have long been frosty. They are now complicated by up to 10,000 deportations a week.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cage-like trucks fitted with iron bars that appear designed to carry livestock line up every morning at the border between Haiti and the Dominican Republic.
articles.byline: By Hogla Enecia Pérez and Frances Robles

articles.headline: Chinese Carmakers Are Taking Mexico by Storm While Eyeing U.S.
articles.snippet: BYD and other manufacturers are importing cars from China and scouting factory sites in Mexico as part of a global expansion that, for now, excludes the United States.
articles.abstract: BYD and other manufacturers are importing cars from China and scouting factory sites in Mexico as part of a global expansion that, for now, excludes the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: Behind a crumbling brick wall in a working-class neighborhood of Mexico City lurks a seemingly innocuous car lot. But it could be a sign of a potentially grave threat to the North American auto industry.

articles.headline: China Opens Investigation Into Nvidia Over Potential Antitrust Violations
articles.snippet: The move by Chinese regulators came a week after the Biden administration expanded curbs on the sale of advanced U.S. technology to China.
articles.abstract: The move by Chinese regulators came a week after the Biden administration expanded curbs on the sale of advanced U.S. technology to China.
articles.lead_paragraph: China’s antimonopoly regulator announced on Monday that it was investigating potential violations of antitrust law by Nvidia, the American company that makes a vast majority of the computer chips that power artificial intelligence systems.
articles.byline: By Meaghan Tobin, John Liu, Ana Swanson and Tripp Mickle

articles.headline: Quantum Computing Inches Closer to Reality After Another Google Breakthrough
articles.snippet: Google unveiled an experimental machine capable of tasks that a traditional supercomputer could not master in 10 septillion years. (That’s older than the universe.)
articles.abstract: Google unveiled an experimental machine capable of tasks that a traditional supercomputer could not master in 10 septillion years. (That’s older than the universe.)
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2019, a team of Google researchers said they had built a machine capable of performing tasks that were not possible with traditional supercomputers. They described this machine, called a quantum computer, as a turning point in the evolution of information technology.
